banner.title: TP WorkLife 10/12
banner.mainContentHeadline: The podcast where science meets business
banner.mainContent: From fixing meetings to finding a mentor, get new insights to help you enjoy your time at work and thrive in your career.

videoData.title: In defense of emojis

nodes.whoTheyAre: Jenna Schilstra grew up in a country divided between two languages: Dutch and French-speaking Belgium. A childhood steeped in languages seeded a lifelong yearning to overcome language barriers and communicate with the unfamiliar. As a customer technology manager on UPS’s mobile strategy team, Schilstra's international perspective has informed the expansion of the company’s mobile presence to 83 countries.

videoData.description: A simple emoji can help clarify and amplify subtext so that we can better understand each other, but their benefits extend far beyond enhancing our daily texts and emails. Marketing analyst and avid emoji-defender Jenna Schilstra demonstrates how these pictograms are being used in new ways, like helping abused children describe complex emotions, or giving new communication methods to people on the autism spectrum. In the end, Schilstra says, these new expressions might be making expression itself more accessible.
